controls.title:
The application must be capable of taking organizational-defined
actions upon audit failure (e.g., overwrite oldest audit records, stop
generating audit records, cease processing, notify of audit failure).
controls.desc:
Monitor the health and resources (such as remaining storage) of
systems running Elasticsearch software and notify operators when safety
thresholds have been exceeded. Automated system notification via email or http
endpoint can be built as an action in Watcher.

tags.check:
Verify the audit records are stored on a separate disk than
operating system.

Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are
being written to with the following command:

# grep log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf log_file =
/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/audit.log

Check the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the
example being \"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/\"):

# df -h /var/log/elasticsearch/audit/ 0.9G /var/log/elasticsearch/audit

If the audit records are not being written to a partition specifically created
for audit records (in this example \"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit\" is a
separate partition), this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure the audit storage to a separate partition for audit
storage.

Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are
being written to:

# grep log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf

Determine the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the
example being \"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/\"):

# df -h /var/log/elasticsearch/audit/

controls.code:
control "V-26974" do
  title "The application must be capable of taking organizational-defined
actions upon audit failure (e.g., overwrite oldest audit records, stop
generating audit records, cease processing, notify of audit failure)."
  desc  "Monitor the health and resources (such as remaining storage) of
systems running Elasticsearch software and notify operators when safety
thresholds have been exceeded. Automated system notification via email or http
endpoint can be built as an action in Watcher."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["AU-5 b", "Rev_4"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34262r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000109"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000140"
  tag "check": "Verify the audit records are stored on a separate disk than
operating system.

Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are
being written to with the following command:

# grep log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf log_file =
/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/audit.log

Check the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the
example being \\\"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/\\\"):

# df -h /var/log/elasticsearch/audit/ 0.9G /var/log/elasticsearch/audit

If the audit records are not being written to a partition specifically created
for audit records (in this example \\\"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit\\\" is a
separate partition), this is a finding."
  tag "fix": "Configure the audit storage to a separate partition for audit
storage.

Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are
being written to:

# grep log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf

Determine the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the
example being \\\"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/\\\"):

# df -h /var/log/elasticsearch/audit/    "

  begin
    log_partition_name = command("df #{AUDITD_LOG_FILE} | awk '/^\\/dev/ {print $1}'").stdout.strip()
    log_partition_size = command("df #{AUDITD_LOG_FILE} | awk '/^\\/dev/ {print $2}'").stdout.strip().to_f / 1000
    space_left = ((AUDITD_SPACE_LEFT_THRESHOLD_PRECENT*0.01) * log_partition_size).round

    describe auditd_conf do
      its('log_file') { should cmp AUDITD_LOG_FILE}
      its('space_left.to_i') { should > space_left}
    end

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe do
      skip "Exception: #{msg}"
    end
  end
end

results.code_desc: Audit Daemon Config log_file should cmp == "/var/log/audit/audit.log"
Audit Daemon Config space_left.to_i should > 9816

controls.title:
The application must alert designated organizational officials in the
event of an audit processing failure.
controls.desc:
Utilize perimeter, application, centralized authentication, and
repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol.

tags.check:
Verify the operating system immediately notifies the SA and
ISSO (at a minimum) when allocated audit record storage volume reaches
<DETERMINED_THRESHOLD> percent of the repository maximum audit record storage
capacity.

Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are
being written to with the following command:

# grep log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf log_file =
/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/audit.log

Check the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the
example being \"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/\"):

# df -h /var/log/elasticsearch/audit/ 0.9G /var/log/elasticsearch/audit

If the audit records are not being written to a partition specifically created
for audit records (in this example \"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit\" is a
separate partition), determine the amount of space other files in the partition
are currently occupying with the following command:

# du -sh <partition> 1.8G /var  Determine what the threshold is for the system
to take action when <DETERMINED_THRESHOLD> percent of the repository maximum
audit record storage capacity is reached:

# grep -i space_left /etc/audit/auditd.conf space_left = 225

If the value of the \"space_left\" keyword is not set to
ABS(1-<DETERMINED_THRESHOLD>) percent of the total partition size, this is a
finding.
tags.fix:
Configure the operating system to immediately notify the SA and
ISSO (at a minimum) when allocated audit record storage volume reaches
<DETERMINED_THRESHOLD> percent of the repository maximum audit record storage
capacity.

Check the system configuration to determine the partition the audit records are
being written to:

# grep log_file /etc/audit/auditd.conf

Determine the size of the partition that audit records are written to (with the
example being \"/var/log/elasticsearch/audit/\"):

# df -h /var/log/elasticsearch/audit/

Set the value of the \"space_left\" keyword in
\"/etc/audit/auditd.conf\" to <DETERMINED_THRESHOLD> percent of the
partition size.

controls.title:
Applications must prevent encrypted data from bypassing
content-checking mechanisms.
controls.desc:
Limit network access to Elasticsearch software from known points of
origin with the use of software and hardware firewalls as well as X-Pack
Security IP Filtering. Change the elasticsearch cluster name to an instance
unique value for all elasticsearch nodes and transport client nodes in the
system.

tags.check:
Check Elasticsearch.yml settings and existing IP filtering
rules to verify that only specific IP behind hardware/software 'Managed
access control points' are listed.

As the application administrator (usually elasticsearch, check the
xpack.security.http.filter setting contains IP address(es) of the  'Managed
access control points':

$cat elasticsearch.yml | grep 'xpack.security.http.filter', Verify all three
settings; xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true;
xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points';
xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

As an elasticsearch administrator test; verify runtime environment within
_culster settings are set to '{}' OR Verify all three settings are
xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true; xpack.security.http.filter.allow:
'Managed access control points'; xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

$curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p <TEST_CREDENTIALS>
-XGET 'http://<elasticsearch>:9200/_cluster/settings'

If these configuration setting are disabled, or not pointing to the 'Managed
access control points', this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-XXX for
instructions on configuring ES_HOME.

To change the Managed access control points of the application, as the
application administrator, change the following setting in elasticsearch.yml:


$ sudo su - elasticsearch
$ vi $ES_HOME/config/elasticsearch.yml

Change the Managed access control points parameter to the desired addresses,
i.e.:
     xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true
     xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points'
     xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

Next, restart the application:
$ sudo su - elasticsearch

# SYSTEMD SERVER ONLY
$ systemctl restart elasticsearch

controls.code:
control "V-26790" do
  title "Applications must prevent encrypted data from bypassing
content-checking mechanisms."
  desc  "Limit network access to Elasticsearch software from known points of
origin with the use of software and hardware firewalls as well as X-Pack
Security IP Filtering. Change the elasticsearch cluster name to an instance
unique value for all elasticsearch nodes and transport client nodes in the
system."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["AC-4 (4)", "Rev_4"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34040r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000056"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000028"
  tag "check": "Check Elasticsearch.yml settings and existing IP filtering
rules to verify that only specific IP behind hardware/software 'Managed
access control points' are listed.

As the application administrator (usually elasticsearch, check the
xpack.security.http.filter setting contains IP address(es) of the  'Managed
access control points':

$cat elasticsearch.yml | grep 'xpack.security.http.filter', Verify all three
settings; xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true;
xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points';
xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

As an elasticsearch administrator test; verify runtime environment within
_culster settings are set to '{}' OR Verify all three settings are
xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true; xpack.security.http.filter.allow:
'Managed access control points'; xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

$curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p <TEST_CREDENTIALS>
-XGET 'http://<elasticsearch>:9200/_cluster/settings'

If these configuration setting are disabled, or not pointing to the 'Managed
access control points', this is a finding. "
  tag "fix": "Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-XXX for
instructions on configuring ES_HOME.

To change the Managed access control points of the application, as the
application administrator, change the following setting in elasticsearch.yml:


$ sudo su - elasticsearch
$ vi $ES_HOME/config/elasticsearch.yml

Change the Managed access control points parameter to the desired addresses,
i.e.:
     xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true
     xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points'
     xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

Next, restart the application:
$ sudo su - elasticsearch

# SYSTEMD SERVER ONLY
$ systemctl restart elasticsearch"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?


    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "IP filtering rules for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.ip_filter }
        its('enabled') { should eq 'true' }
        its('allow')  { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
        its('deny') { should eq '_all' }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    describe "IP filtering rules" do
      subject { yaml(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.enabled']) { should eq true }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.allow']) { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.deny']) { should eq '_all' }
    end

    describe "Cluster Setting:" do
      subject{ es_handle.cluster_settings }
      its(['persistent']) { should be_empty }
      its(['transient']) { should be_empty }
    end

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

Security IP Filtering. Change the elasticsearch cluster name to an instance
unique value for all elasticsearch nodes and all applications should use HTTP/S
 rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["AC-17 (8)", "Rev_3"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-33911r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000020"
  tag "cci": "CCI-001436"
  tag "check": "Check Elasticsearch.yml settings and existing IP filtering
rules to verify that only specific IP behind hardware/software 'Managed
access control points' are listed.

As the application administrator (usually elasticsearch, check the
xpack.security.http.filter setting contains IP address(es) of the  'Managed
access control points':

$cat elasticsearch.yml | grep 'xpack.security.http.filter', Verify all three
settings; xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true;
xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points';
xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

As an elasticsearch administrator test; verify runtime environment within
_culster settings are set to '{}' OR Verify all three settings are
xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true; xpack.security.http.filter.allow:
'Managed access control points'; xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

$ curl -h content_type:application-json    -XGET
'http://<elasticsearch>:9200/_cluster/settings'

If these configuration setting are disabled, or not pointing to the 'Managed
access control points', this is a finding. "
  tag "fix": "Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-XXX for
instructions on configuring ES_HOME.

To change the Managed access control points of the application, as the
application administrator, change the following setting in elasticsearch.yml:


$ sudo su - elasticsearch
$ vi $ES_HOME/config/elasticsearch.yml

Change the Managed access control points parameter to the desired addresses,
i.e.:
     xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true
     xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points'
     xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

Next, restart the application:
$ sudo su - elasticsearch

# SYSTEMD SERVER ONLY
$ systemctl restart elasticsearch"
  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?


    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "IP filtering rules for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.ip_filter }
        its('enabled') { should eq 'true' }
        its('allow')  { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
        its('deny') { should eq '_all' }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    describe "IP filtering rules" do
      subject { yaml(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.enabled']) { should eq true }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.allow']) { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.deny']) { should eq '_all' }
    end

    describe "Cluster Setting:" do
      subject{ es_handle.cluster_settings }
      its(['persistent']) { should be_empty }
      its(['transient']) { should be_empty }
    end

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

controls.title:
The application must ensure remote sessions for accessing an
organizational-defined list of security functions and security-relevant
information are audited.
controls.desc:
Utilize perimeter, application, centralized authentication, and
repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol.

tags.check:
Check Elasticsearch.yml settings and existing IP filtering
rules to verify that only specific IP behind hardware/software 'Managed
access control points' are listed.

xpack.security.http.filter setting contains IP address(es) of the  'Managed
access control points':

xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points';
xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

As an elasticsearch administrator test; verify runtime environment within
_culster settings are set to '{}' OR Verify all three settings are
xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true; xpack.security.http.filter.allow:
'Managed access control points'; xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

$ curl -h content_type:application-json    -XGET
'http://<elasticsearch>:9200/_cluster/settings'

If these configuration setting are disabled, or not pointing to the 'Managed
access control points', this is a finding.

     xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

access control points', this is a finding. "
  tag "fix": "Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment

instructions on configuring ES_HOME.

To change the Managed access control points of the application, as the
application administrator, change the following setting in elasticsearch.yml:

$ vi $ES_HOME/config/elasticsearch.yml

Change the Managed access control points parameter to the desired addresses,
i.e.:

      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.allow']) { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.deny']) { should eq '_all' }
    end

    describe "Cluster Setting:" do

      its(['transient']) { should be_empty }
    end

  rescue Exception => msg

  end
end

controls.title: The application must protect audit tools from unauthorized access.
controls.desc:
Utilize perimeter, application, centralized authentication, and
repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol.

tags.check:
The owner of all log files written by the application should be
elasticsearch. These log files are determined by the
xpack.security.audit.output parameter in elasticsearch.yml and typically all
appear in /var/log/elasticsearch/audit. To see the owner of a given log file,
run the following command:

$ ls -l LOGFILE

If the owner is not root, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
The owner of all log files written by the application should be
elasticsearch. These log files are determined by the
xpack.security.audit.output parameter in elasticsearch.yml and typically all
appear in /var/log/elasticsearch/audit.

For each log file LOGFILE referenced in /etc/rsyslog.conf, run the following
command to inspect the file's owner:

$ ls -l LOGFILE

If the owner is not elasticsearch, run the following command to correct this:

$ sudo chown elasticsearch LOGFILE

control "V-27163" do
  title "The application must protect audit tools from unauthorized access."

controls.title:
Applications must support organizational requirements to disable user
accounts after an organizational-defined time period of inactivity.
controls.desc:
Configure the centralized authentication service to enforce
organizational policies such as password strength, lockout, expiration,
notification, and screen obfuscation.

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

Elasticsearch supports LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'
          bind_dn: 'cn=ldapuser, ou=users, o=services, dc=example, dc=com'
          bind_password: changeme
          user_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
            attribute: cn
          group_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
          files:
            role_mapping: 'CONFIG_DIR/x-pack/role_mapping.yml

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is PKI; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html

controls.code:
control "V-26914" do
  title "Applications must support organizational requirements to disable user
accounts after an organizational-defined time period of inactivity."
  desc  "Configure the centralized authentication service to enforce
organizational policies such as password strength, lockout, expiration,
notification, and screen obfuscation."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["IA-4 e", "Rev_4"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34194r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000163"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000795"
  tag "check": "Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

Elasticsearch supports LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \\?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'
          bind_dn: 'cn=ldapuser, ou=users, o=services, dc=example, dc=com'
          bind_password: changeme
          user_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
            attribute: cn
          group_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
          files:
            role_mapping: 'CONFIG_DIR/x-pack/role_mapping.yml

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is PKI; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

"
  tag "fix": "Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html"


  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?


    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Authentication methods includes AD, LDAP or PKI for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.authc_method.any? { |x| ['pki','active_directory','ldap'].include?(x) } }
        it{ should be true }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe.one do
        node.authc_realm.keys.each do |auth_method|
          describe "Active Directory Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('domain_name') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('unmapped_groups_as_roles') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('active_directory')

          describe "LDAP Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('bind_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('bind_password') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.attribute') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('group_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('files.role_mapping') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('ldap')

          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

control "V-26920" do
  title "The application must support organizational requirements to enforce
password complexity by the number of numeric characters used."

organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,

            its ('domain_name') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('unmapped_groups_as_roles') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('active_directory')

            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }

            its ('user_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.attribute') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('group_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('files.role_mapping') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('ldap')

          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol.

  begin

            its ('files.role_mapping') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('ldap')

            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

control "V-30583" do
  title "The application must notify appropriate individuals when accounts are
terminated."

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?pki'

organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

        node.authc_realm.keys.each do |auth_method|
          describe "Active Directory Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('domain_name') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('unmapped_groups_as_roles') { should_not be_nil }

            its ('bind_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('bind_password') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.attribute') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('group_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('files.role_mapping') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('ldap')

          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

controls.title:
Applications required to identify devices must uniquely identify and
authenticate an organizational-defined list of specific and/or types of devices
before establishing a connection.
controls.desc:
Configure the Elasticsearch cluster to use a centralized
authentication and authorization service such as Active Directory or LDAP in
order to comply with organizational defined management policies.

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

Elasticsearch supports LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'
          bind_dn: 'cn=ldapuser, ou=users, o=services, dc=example, dc=com'
          bind_password: changeme
          user_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
            attribute: cn
          group_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
          files:
            role_mapping: 'CONFIG_DIR/x-pack/role_mapping.yml

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is PKI; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html

controls.title:
Application users must utilize a separate, distinct administrative
account when accessing application security functions or security-relevant
information. Non-privileged accounts must be utilized when accessing
non-administrative application functions. The application must provide this
functionality itself or leverage an existing technology providing this
capability.
controls.desc:
Separate the access point and accounts used to administer
Elasticsearch by configuring different user interfaces and issuing separate
administrative accounts for the use of administrators taking administrative
actions. Prevent Administrative interfaces and accounts should not be used for
non-administrative actions by using X-Pack's RBAC to enforce separation of
duties. Audit and alert on the actions of administrator accounts to assure they
are not being used for non-administrative action.

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

For all other accounts, admin and non-administrative should be handled
externally by LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'

controls.code:
control "V-26827" do
  title "Application users must utilize a separate, distinct administrative
account when accessing application security functions or security-relevant
information. Non-privileged accounts must be utilized when accessing
non-administrative application functions. The application must provide this
functionality itself or leverage an existing technology providing this
capability."
  desc  "Separate the access point and accounts used to administer
Elasticsearch by configuring different user interfaces and issuing separate
administrative accounts for the use of administrators taking administrative
actions. Prevent Administrative interfaces and accounts should not be used for
non-administrative actions by using X-Pack's RBAC to enforce separation of
duties. Audit and alert on the actions of administrator accounts to assure they
are not being used for non-administrative action."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["AC-6 (2)", "Rev_3"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34077r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000063"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000040"
  tag "check": "Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

For all other accounts, admin and non-administrative should be handled
externally by LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \\?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'
          bind_dn: 'cn=ldapuser, ou=users, o=services, dc=example, dc=com'
          bind_password: changeme
          user_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
            attribute: cn
          group_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
          files:
            role_mapping: 'CONFIG_DIR/x-pack/role_mapping.yml

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is PKI; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

"
  tag "fix": "Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html"


  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?


    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Authentication methods includes AD, LDAP or PKI for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.authc_method.any? { |x| ['pki','active_directory','ldap'].include?(x) } }
        it{ should be true }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe.one do
        node.authc_realm.keys.each do |auth_method|
          describe "Active Directory Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('domain_name') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('unmapped_groups_as_roles') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('active_directory')

          describe "LDAP Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('bind_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('bind_password') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('user_search.attribute') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('group_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('files.role_mapping') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('ldap')

          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

controls.title:

users account, the application upon successful logon/access must display to the

logon/access.
controls.desc:
Configure the centralized authentication service to enforce

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

Elasticsearch supports LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'
          bind_dn: 'cn=ldapuser, ou=users, o=services, dc=example, dc=com'
          bind_password: changeme
          user_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
            attribute: cn
          group_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
          files:
            role_mapping: 'CONFIG_DIR/x-pack/role_mapping.yml

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is PKI; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

  begin

            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

          describe "Active Directory Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { es_handle.settings.first.xpack.security.authc.realms[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('domain_name') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('url') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('unmapped_groups_as_roles') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('active_directory')

          describe "LDAP Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do

            its ('group_search.base_dn') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('files.role_mapping') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('ldap')

          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

controls.title:
The application must notify the user of the number of unsuccessful
login/access attempts occurring during an organizational-defined time period.
controls.desc:
Configure the centralized authentication service to enforce
organizational policies such as password strength, lockout, expiration,
notification, and screen obfuscation.

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce password complexity rules.

Elasticsearch supports LDAP, Active Directory, and PKI.

If the external authentication is Active Directory; verify the following
settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?active_directory'


 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        active_directory:
          type: active_directory
          order: 0
          domain_name: ad.example.com
          url: ldaps://ad.example.com:636
          unmapped_groups_as_roles: true | false

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is LDAP; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 16 -B 6 'type: \?ldap'

xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        ldap1:
          type: ldap
          order: 0
          url: 'ldaps://ldap.example.com:636'
          bind_dn: 'cn=ldapuser, ou=users, o=services, dc=example, dc=com'
          bind_password: changeme
          user_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
            attribute: cn
          group_search:
            base_dn: 'dc=example,dc=com'
          files:
            role_mapping: 'CONFIG_DIR/x-pack/role_mapping.yml

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

If the external authentication is PKI; verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html

controls.title:
The application must enforce approved authorizations for logical
access to the system in accordance with applicable policy.
controls.desc:
Plan for granting temporary authorizations, with known automated
expiration times, to enable users to implement out of the ordinary processes.

tags.check:
Verify that role-based policies are in place and access
enforcement mechanisms are in place.

As the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:

$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is incorrect or provides access to
cluster configuration outside of administrative roles, this is a finding.

Check Elasticsearch.yml settings and existing IP filtering rules to verify that
only specific IP behind hardware/software 'Managed access control points'
are listed.

As the application administrator (usually elasticsearch, check the
xpack.security.http.filter setting contains IP address(es) of the  'Managed
access control points':

$cat elasticsearch.yml | grep 'xpack.security.http.filter', Verify all three
settings; xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true;
xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points';
xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

As an elasticsearch administrator test; verify runtime environment within
_culster settings are set to '{}' OR Verify all three settings are
xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true; xpack.security.http.filter.allow:
'Managed access control points'; xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

$curl -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p <TEST_CREDENTIALS>
 -XGET 'http://<elasticsearch>:9200/_cluster/settings'

If these configuration setting are disabled, or not pointing to the 'Managed
access control points', this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Implement strong access controls to secure application data by
establishing role-based policies and access control mechanisms.

To establish role-based policies; see the official documentation on
authorization;
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/authorization.html.

Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment variable. See
supplementary content APPENDIX-XXX for instructions on configuring ES_HOME.

To establish an access control mechanism; as the application administrator,
change the following setting in elasticsearch.yml:

$ sudo su - elasticsearch
$ vi $ES_HOME/config/elasticsearch.yml

Change the Managed access control points parameter to the desired addresses,
i.e.:
     xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true
     xpack.security.http.filter.allow: 'Managed access control points'
     xpack.security.http.filter.deny: _all

Next, restart the application:
$ sudo su - elasticsearch

# SYSTEMD SERVER ONLY
$ systemctl restart elasticsearch

To establish role-based policies; see the official documentation on

https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/authorization.html.

Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment variable. See
supplementary content APPENDIX-XXX for instructions on configuring ES_HOME.

To establish an access control mechanism; as the application administrator,
change the following setting in elasticsearch.yml:

$ sudo su - elasticsearch
$ vi $ES_HOME/config/elasticsearch.yml

Change the Managed access control points parameter to the desired addresses,
i.e.:
     xpack.security.http.filter.enabled: true

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",

      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?

    describe es_handle do
      its('superusers') { should be_in DOCUMENTED_SUPER_ROLES}
    end

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "IP filtering rules for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.ip_filter }
        its('enabled') { should eq 'true' }
        its('allow')  { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
        its('deny') { should eq '_all' }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    describe "IP filtering rules" do
      subject { yaml(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.enabled']) { should eq true }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.allow']) { should be_in MANAGED_ACCESS_POINTS }
      its(['xpack.security.http.filter.deny']) { should eq '_all' }
    end

    describe "Cluster Setting:" do
      subject{ es_handle.cluster_settings }
      its(['persistent']) { should be_empty }
      its(['transient']) { should be_empty }
    end

controls.title:
The application must employ automated mechanisms to facilitate the
monitoring and control of remote access methods.
controls.desc:
Collect Elasticsearch X-Pack Security audit records from all
Elasticsearch nodes in near-real time to enable audit monitoring.

tags.check:
Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit

Check elasticsearch settings and documentation to determine whether designated
personnel are able to select which auditable events are being audited.


As the application administrator (shown here as 'elasticsearch'), verify the
permissions for ES_HOME:

$ ls -la ${ES_HOME?}

If anything in ES_HOME is not owned by the application administrator, this is a
finding.

Next, as the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:


$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is listed as superuser but should not
have that access, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch audit settings to audit access methods.

See the official documentation for the instructions on audit configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/auditing.html

controls.code:
control "V-26684" do
  title "The application must employ automated mechanisms to facilitate the
monitoring and control of remote access methods."
  desc  "Collect Elasticsearch X-Pack Security audit records from all
Elasticsearch nodes in near-real time to enable audit monitoring."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["AC-17 (1)", "Rev_4"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-33904r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000016"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000067"
  tag "check": "Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit

Check elasticsearch settings and documentation to determine whether designated
personnel are able to select which auditable events are being audited.


As the application administrator (shown here as 'elasticsearch'), verify the
permissions for ES_HOME:

$ ls -la ${ES_HOME?}

If anything in ES_HOME is not owned by the application administrator, this is a
finding.

Next, as the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:


$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is listed as superuser but should not
have that access, this is a finding."
  tag "fix": "Configure elasticsearch audit settings to audit access methods.

See the official documentation for the instructions on audit configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/auditing.html"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Audit Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.audit }
        its('enabled') { should eq 'true' }
        its('outputs') { should include 'logfile' }
        its('logfile.events.include') { should match_array ES_INCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
        its('logfile.events.exclude') { should match_array ES_EXCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    describe "Audit Settings from ES_CONF_YML" do
      subject { yaml(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.enabled']) { should eq true }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.outputs']) { should include 'logfile' }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.include']) { should match_array ES_INCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.exclude']) { should match_array ES_EXCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
    end

    describe "ES HOME directory" do
      subject { file(ES_HOME) }
      its('owner') { should eq ES_OWNER }
      its('group') { should eq ES_GROUP }
    end

    describe "ES CONF" do
      subject { file(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its('owner') { should eq ES_OWNER }
      its('group') { should eq ES_GROUP }
    end

    describe es_handle do
      its('superusers') { should be_in DOCUMENTED_SUPER_ROLES}
    end
    
  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

controls.title:
In support of information flow requirements, applications must track
problems associated with information transfer.
controls.desc:
Utilize perimeter, application, centralized authentication, and
repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol.

tags.check:
Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit

Check elasticsearch settings and documentation to determine whether designated
personnel are able to select which auditable events are being audited.


As the application administrator (shown here as 'elasticsearch'), verify the
permissions for ES_HOME:

$ ls -la ${ES_HOME?}

If anything in ES_HOME is not owned by the application administrator, this is a
finding.

Next, as the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:


$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is listed as superuser but should not
have that access, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch audit settings to audit access methods.

See the official documentation for the instructions on audit configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/auditing.html

controls.title:
Applications must provide the capability to automatically process
audit records for events of interest based upon selectable, event criteria.
controls.desc:
Deploy security analytics to monitor the behavior of system users and
administrators. Audit events should be exportable, searchable, filterable, and
summarized in real time.

tags.check:
Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit

Check elasticsearch settings and documentation to determine whether designated
personnel are able to select which auditable events are being audited.


As the application administrator (shown here as 'elasticsearch'), verify the
permissions for ES_HOME:

$ ls -la ${ES_HOME?}

If anything in ES_HOME is not owned by the application administrator, this is a
finding.

Next, as the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:


$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is listed as superuser but should not
have that access, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch audit settings based on selectable, event
criteria.

See the official documentation for the instructions on audit configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/auditing.html

controls.code:
control "V-27145" do
  title "Applications must provide the capability to automatically process
audit records for events of interest based upon selectable, event criteria."
  desc  "Deploy security analytics to monitor the behavior of system users and
administrators. Audit events should be exportable, searchable, filterable, and
summarized in real time."

variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Audit Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.audit }
        its('enabled') { should eq 'true' }
        its('outputs') { should include 'logfile' }
        its('logfile.events.include') { should match_array ES_INCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
        its('logfile.events.exclude') { should match_array ES_EXCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

      subject { yaml(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }

      its(['xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.include']) { should match_array ES_INCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.exclude']) { should match_array ES_EXCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
    end

      its('owner') { should eq ES_OWNER }
      its('group') { should eq ES_GROUP }
    end

    describe "ES CONF" do
      subject { file(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its('owner') { should eq ES_OWNER }
      its('group') { should eq ES_GROUP }
    end

    describe es_handle do
      its('superusers') { should be_in DOCUMENTED_SUPER_ROLES}
    end
    
  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

controls.title:
The application must protect audit tools from unauthorized
modification.
controls.desc:
Utilize perimeter, application, centralized authentication, and
repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol. Implement OS
level access controls on audit logs. Move audit logs off of elasticsearch
systems and into central audit logging solution.

tags.check:
Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit.outputs


Check elasticsearch settings and documentation to determine whether designated
personnel are able to access audit settings.

As the application administrator (shown here as 'elasticsearch'), verify the
permissions for ES_HOME:

$ ls -la ${ES_HOME?}

If anything in ES_HOME is not owned by the application administrator, this is a
finding.

Next, as the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:


$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is listed as superuser but should not
have that access, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch audit settings to be controlled by
authorized users.

See the official documentation for the instructions on audit configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/auditing.html

controls.code:
control "V-27164" do
  title "The application must protect audit tools from unauthorized
modification."
  desc  "Utilize perimeter, application, centralized authentication, and
repository audit controls to audit the use of systems in real time with
sufficient context.  X-Pack Security audit controls should be enabled to audit
the defaults of all HTTP/S based access to Elasticsearch.  All applications
should use HTTP/S  rather than Elasticsearch transport protocol. Implement OS
level access controls on audit logs. Move audit logs off of elasticsearch
systems and into central audit logging solution."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["AU-9", "Rev_4"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34463r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000122"
  tag "cci": "CCI-001494"
  tag "check": "Note: The following instructions use the ES_HOME environment
variable. See supplementary content APPENDIX-F for instructions on configuring
ES_HOME.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep xpack.security.audit.outputs


Check elasticsearch settings and documentation to determine whether designated
personnel are able to access audit settings.

As the application administrator (shown here as 'elasticsearch'), verify the
permissions for ES_HOME:

$ ls -la ${ES_HOME?}

If anything in ES_HOME is not owned by the application administrator, this is a
finding.

Next, as the elasticsearch administrator, run the following CURL command:


$ curl -XGET  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -u <TEST_USER> -p
<TEST_CREDENTIALS> https://<elasticsearch>:9200/_xpack/security/role

Review the role permissions, if any role is listed as superuser but should not
have that access, this is a finding."
  tag "fix": "Configure elasticsearch audit settings to be controlled by
authorized users.

See the official documentation for the instructions on audit configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/auditing.html"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Audit Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node.audit }
        its('enabled') { should eq 'true' }
        its('outputs') { should include 'logfile' }
        its('logfile.events.include') { should match_array ES_INCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
        its('logfile.events.exclude') { should match_array ES_EXCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    describe "Audit Settings from ES_CONF_YML" do
      subject { yaml(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.enabled']) { should eq true }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.outputs']) { should include 'logfile' }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.include']) { should match_array ES_INCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
      its(['xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.exclude']) { should match_array ES_EXCLUDED_LOGEVENTS }
    end

    describe "ES HOME directory" do
      subject { file(ES_HOME) }
      its('owner') { should eq ES_OWNER }
      its('group') { should eq ES_GROUP }
    end

    describe "ES CONF" do
      subject { file(ELASTICSEARCH_CONF) }
      its('owner') { should eq ES_OWNER }
      its('group') { should eq ES_GROUP }
    end

    describe es_handle do
      its('superusers') { should be_in DOCUMENTED_SUPER_ROLES}
    end
    
  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

Audit Settings for Node: package-centos-72 outputs should include "logfile"

Audit Settings for Node: package-centos-72 logfile.events.exclude should contain exactly "access_granted"

Audit Settings from ES_CONF_YML ["xpack.security.audit.logfile.events.exclude"] should contain exactly "access_granted"

controls.title:
The application must use multifactor authentication for network access
to non-privileged accounts.
controls.desc:
Within X-Pack Security, a Custom Realm can be implemented that
fulfills multifactor authentication. Multifactor checks can be integrated
within the single custom realm.

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce multifactor authentication.

Elasticsearch only supports PKI for multifactor authentication; to ensure PKI
is enabled, verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html

controls.code:
control "V-26975" do
  title "The application must use multifactor authentication for network access
to non-privileged accounts."
  desc  "Within X-Pack Security, a Custom Realm can be implemented that
fulfills multifactor authentication. Multifactor checks can be integrated
within the single custom realm."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["IA-2 (2)", "Rev_4"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34263r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000150"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000766"
  tag "check": "Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce multifactor authentication.

Elasticsearch only supports PKI for multifactor authentication; to ensure PKI
is enabled, verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

"
  tag "fix": "Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?


    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Authentication methods includes PKI for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node }
        its('authc_method') { should include 'pki' }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe.one do
        node.authc_realm.keys.each do |auth_method|
          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

results.code_desc: Authentication methods includes PKI for Node: package-centos-72 authc_method should include "pki"
PKI Settings for Node: package-centos-72 order should not be nil
PKI Settings for Node: package-centos-72 username_pattern should not be nil

controls.desc:
Within X-Pack Security, a Custom Realm can be implemented that
fulfills multifactor authentication. Multifactor checks can be integrated
within the single custom realm.

tags.check:
Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce multifactor authentication.

Elasticsearch only supports PKI for multifactor authentication; to ensure PKI
is enabled, verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.
tags.fix:
Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html

controls.code:
control "V-26981" do
  title "Applications using multifactor authentication when accessing
non-privileged accounts via the network must provide one of the factors by a
device separate from the information system gaining access."
  desc  "Within X-Pack Security, a Custom Realm can be implemented that
fulfills multifactor authentication. Multifactor checks can be integrated
within the single custom realm."
  impact 0.5
  tag "nist": ["IA-2 (7)", "Rev_3"]
  tag "severity": "medium"
  tag "rid": "SV-34270r1_rule"
  tag "gtitle": "SRG-APP-000155"
  tag "cci": "CCI-000772"
  tag "check": "Guidance in Appendix B - System accounts cannot be disabled and
elasticsearch does not enforce multifactor authentication.

Elasticsearch only supports PKI for multifactor authentication; to ensure PKI
is enabled, verify the following settings.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 6 -B 6 'type: \\?pki'

 xpack:
  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

"
  tag "fix": "Configure elasticsearch realms settings to point to
organizational supported authentication mechanism

See the official documentation for the instructions on realm configuration:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html"

  begin

    es_handle = es_helper(url:"https://#{ELASTIC_IP}:#{ELASTIC_PORT}",
                    username: ES_ADMIN,
                    password: ES_PASS,
                    ssl_verify: SSL_VERIFY )

    describe "No nodes found" do
      subject { es_handle.nodes.nil? }
      it { should_not be_truthy }
    end if es_handle.nodes.nil?


    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe "Authentication methods includes PKI for Node: #{node.name}" do
        subject { node }
        its('authc_method') { should include 'pki' }
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

    es_handle.nodes.each do |node|
      describe.one do
        node.authc_realm.keys.each do |auth_method|
          describe "PKI Settings for Node: #{node.name}" do
            subject { node.authc_realm[auth_method] }
            its ('order') { should_not be_nil }
            its ('username_pattern') { should_not be_nil }
          end if node.authc_realm[auth_method].type.eql?('pki')
        end
      end
    end unless es_handle.nodes.nil?

  rescue Exception => msg
    describe "Exception: #{msg}" do
      it { should be_nil}
    end
  end
end

PKI Settings for Node: package-centos-72 username_pattern should not be nil

controls.title:
The application, when utilizing PKI-based authentication, must
validate certificates by constructing a certification path with status
information to an accepted trust anchor.
controls.desc:
Configure the centralized authentication service to enforce
organizational policies such as valid certification path, trusted anchor,
certificate revocation lists.

tags.check:
When using PKI-based authentication; the certificate path must
be validated.

$ cat config/elasticsearch.yml | grep -A 10 -B 6 'type: \?pki'

  security:
    authc:
      realms:
        pki1:
          type: pki
          username_pattern: 'EMAILADDRESS=(.*?)(?:,|$)'
          certificate_authorities: <CA_PATH>
          truststore.path: <TS_PATH>

If these settings are not correct or missing, this is a finding.

https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/x-pack/current/_how_authentication_works.html
